event.title: Today the land is mostly given

data.event: Today the land is mostly given over to cattle and chicken farming.

event.title: was discovered near the town in 1983

data.event: The world's largest dinosaur trackway was discovered near the town in 1983.
Mine Creek Baptist Church was built along the banks of Mine Creek by the Rev. Isaac Cooper Perkins (1790–1852) in the area where Nashville now stands around 1835.

event.title: a post stop along the settlement roads in 1840

data.event: Settlers later established a post stop along the settlement roads in 1840, and a post office incorporated in 1848.
Settlers later established a post stop along the settlement roads in 1840, and a post office incorporated in 1848.
Michael Womack (1794–1861), a Tennessee native reputed to have killed the British General Edward Packenham during the War of 1812, settled in the area with his family in 1849.

event.title: was officially incorporated as Nashville on 18 October 1883

data.event: Following the war, the village's prospects improved, industry and settlement picked up, and the town was officially incorporated as Nashville on 18 October 1883, with D.A. Hutchinson serving as the first mayor.

event.title: The following year, Nashville and Hope were connected

data.event: The following year, Nashville and Hope were connected via railroad, spurring further growth, and the county seat was relocated from Center Point to Nashville.
The town had a population of 928 in 1900, and boasted "a cotton-compress and gin" and a "bottling-works"; by 1920 the population had risen to 2,144.
